Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: To whom it may concern:

I believe it is vitally important for Clallam County citizens to know some truths about the Port of Port Angeles and its support of the CRTC from a person who has first hand knowledge.

Fact: The Port was awarded a $2M reimbursable grant from the US Department of Commerce’s Economic Development Administration to offset funds the Port spent building out the Port owned CRTC building. (EDA Project Number: 07 01 07214). One of the conditions of that reimbursable grant was that the Port charge “fair commercial rental value.” While working at the Port, among other things, I was tasked with oversight of the Port’s business with the CRTC including working toward a long-term lease with the CRTC that would meet EDA approval. During this work, I discovered Port Executive Director Karen Goschen had executed a Memorandum of Understanding that committed the Port to a ten year lease with the CRTC at a rental rate below fair market value. 

COMMENT PART 1

Comment: In addition to being adversely affected at some work settings, employers and school admissions offices increasingly screen applicant's social media content. It's easy to advocate for transparency if you are retired or your career and workplace are tolerant of diverse opinions and free speech.  If not, you better avoid using your name. 

Personally, I want to hear the views of folks in such circumstances, and they are often eager to have a safe space, somewhere, to freely express themselves. This is different from whistle blowing, per se, and it certainly isn't citizen journalism. It's reader comments and observation on journalism and coverage of local issues. 

What we're doing here now isn't journalism, its participating in a reader comments section. If CB wants to claim our comments are journalism, then it should hire us, pay us for them, post our names and bios and exert editorial control. That's journalism.  It's a distinguished  profession, not an open reader comment section.

Sure would be nice if bishops were appointed from among the clergy of a diocese -- from among those who have served in that area, know its needs, have roots and contacts among its people, and a vested interest in those people, not just a temporary assignment of strangers on their (hopeful) way up the ladder. Issues of local favoritism would no doubt be raised, but we see that among the strangers assigned to us anyway.  Experience of other dioceses/areas is valuable, but they don't need to be assigned to those dioceses to benefit from that (and there aren't enough years in anyone's life to experience every other diocese anyway).

Atz Lee falling off a 40 foot cliff, what makes one think that there is no drama in the show and has to be made up ? I travel all over the nation and when people ask me where I am from and say Homer, the first thing they want to know if I know the Kilchrers. The Klichers are living a lifestyle that people have a longing for deep in their soul. To be one with nature and compromise and win without selling out to corporate America . The show has a big fan base and men like Otto and his adventures.

Comment: The budget priorities of the "leadership" of the University system clearly puts athletics before education and research. Cole's numbers mean an average subsidy of over $43,000 a year for each athlete. I don't believe that the many adjunct faculty are paid even half that. An untenured prof may cost more, but not much. 
If there really are fans for these sports, then they need to step up and provide financial support. APU has a Nordic program that has a well earned international reputation and seems to have more Alaskans than UAA & UAF. That school certainly isn't subsidizing it to the tune of $40,000 per athlete per year while the top skiers travel and compete nationally and internationally. Alaskans are getting little return on athletics (how many fans travel to Outside UAA/UAF events or even attend local ones?) and spending ever rarer state dollars and cutting educational programs to do it. We may not care how they do it Outside, but we don't need to make the same mistakes.

Comment: This is a non-issue. The Explorers, a co-ed affiliate of the BSA (but is usually more vocationally based -- law enforcement, fire, medical, aviation, science, business, trades, etc.) has existed for decades in the US for boys and girls 13 or 14 and up. Basically the BSA is becoming pre-Explorers. My brother and I were both Scouts in the 70's and 80's. We both had friends, male and female, who were Explorers as well. My teenage daughters were Girl Scouts in VA up until 2012 when we moved to GA. Most Girl Scout Troops are school-based and when they are full they are full -- there were not enough volunteer moms to allow larger troops, so my daughters were not able to join Girl Scouts in GA. This route may have been a suitable alternative for them.

Almost everyone had studded tires & a lot of people used them year round as there was no fine or law against doing so. I don't believe studs help much except in a narrow temperature range. I strongly believe our road deterioration is due more to poor roadbed construction & materials. Quit pitting one group against another to raise revenue. Calculate the budget shortfall & divide the costs amongst budget cuts, business taxes, income tax, seasonal sales tax, & Dividend reductions equally.

All the things you suggest are the sort of thing that a large company, like BMW, Mercedes, GM (who already have extensive electric car knowledge) and others could implement within a few years if they feel the demand is there.  On the flip side even Tesla's most optimistic projections don't have them ramping up manufacturing capacity to anything close to the level of these companies in the next decade.

Tesla may be acting like a bit of a disruptive technology, but their stock valuation is HIGHLY speculative and not backed by any real-world advantages they might have.

Comment: The problem with attempting to enforce regulation on this market is the same as it has always been: this is a product that can be grown by the acre and sold by the gram, but because of the legal status there was profitability as a reward for risk-taking.

Now, however, the crown has signaled that it will remove this risk i.e. decriminalize it. As as result we are now witnessing the gold rush driven by what the price *used* to be, and that will undoubtedly yeild a vast supply of decent quality marijuana that will available quasi-legally for next to nothing. 

With dramatically lowered very low barriers to entry the grey-market supply side will explode, much more than the demand side. There will be very heavy downward pressure on prices. Even when there was a relatively high barrier (i.e. it was illegal) profitability had been eroding for  years as the state demonstrated its complete inability to enforce the law. Now we're supposed to believe they can "regulate" it. I doubt it.

Comment: And what % of the road surface do the bikes occupy vs the motor vehicle?  Especially when we're talking dedicated bike lanes?  On Broadway it's something like 1/6th of the road surface, although that's probably the worst case.  But on many other roads with narrow dedicated bike lanes it's still something like 5-10% of the road surface dedicated to bikes, and of course it's 100% when it's a bike path built outside of the road completely.

Most of total road costs are not from repairing vehicle damage.  Most of it is in building the roads and bridges in the first place.  Vehicle damage is part of maintenance cost, along with damage from weathering (especially freeze/thaw cycles), snow plow damage, utility crews ripping up and patching roads, and other such factors.  It's a known fact that it costs a lot more to maintain CO roads that it does in AZ because of weather.

Obviously bikes do less damage than motor vehicles, but we shouldn't pretend that's where most of the cost occurs from.

Comment: Headlines like these are what cause retail investors to sell bonds to load up on equities - usually at the exact wrong moment.     The case for owing government, and - to a lesser extent - high quality corporate bonds is that they protect your capital in a way that REIT's, High Yield Bonds and other alternatives do not.   They are negatively correlated to stocks.   They tend to pop when stocks tumble.     If you can't stomach large swings in the value of your investments you must hold a portion of your money in fixed income - or fixed income's poorer cousin; cash.

Comment: The evidence is clear-later start times benefit teenage students. But this is outweighed by perceived advantages. 
In my area, school buses make two runs: early for the 8 am  high school (the earliest time permitted by provincial statute), and later for elementary. 
*This saves tens of thousands per year because fewer buses and drivers are needed. 
*Employers like the earlier start time because they can get their minimum wage workers into stores and restaurants faster. 
*Parents like having the older sibling available to baby sit younger ones-free child care.
None of these "advantages" have anything to do with student learning, unless you think teaching kids hard lessons about labour and economics on their own backs is a worthwhile pursuit.

Comment: I understand that you shift the explanation of the hospital’s poor financial performance onto the declining reimbursement from Medicare & Medicaid to the hospital. The “horrible and unsustainable financial results” you refer to directly relates to how the hospital follows the Medicare & Medicaid guidelines. The US government administers these programs and has under the recommendation and guidance of the Specialty Society Relative Value Scale Update Committee, composed of physicians associated with the American Medical Association, give reimbursement standards for patient care. If the hospital does not follow the guidelines then it will not be reimbursed for the patient and the hospital will lose money. The amount of people covered under Medicare & Medicaid that use the hospital will amplify the losses in direct proportion; therefore, it is the responsibility of the hospital to comply with the regulations to avoid losses. Regulations to protect against fraud, waste, & abuse.

Comment: Mr. Cole, you need to read the statute.  The realized earnings of the Permanent Fund (PF) are NOT fed directly into the Earnings Reserve.  Instead, 21% of the total earnings over 5 years are distributed 50/50 into the Earnings Reserve (ER) and the Permanent Fund Dividend distribution fund (PFD).  The ER (not including the PFD funding) is then reinvested in more liquid instruments than the Corpus of the PF does not need to be touched and can keep growing for the future.  The ER is available to the legislature (through a two-thirds consensus vote) at any time for NECESSARY government functions.  So, if they want to cover the $2.8 billion deficit with these funds this year, they can.  Do I want them to?  NO.  I want them to use a combination of cuts and ER funds to work for 3 years on reducing the ENTIRE governmental budget, regardless of UGF, DF or Administrative funding name.

Comment: 2/2
-Reforming the culture of the curia begins with imbuing those who serve there with an understanding that they have, and ought to have, no authority in the church, and certainly no authority over local bishops. The Curia exists to facilitate a ministry of service to the bishops.
-Authentic reform requires the restoration of the mechanisms of collegiality -- Synods, Conferences and Councils. Following the principle of subsidiarity, many functions now reserved to the Roman Curia -- including the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith -- ought to be dispersed to regional or national conferences of bishops.
-The right of the local church to participate in the selection of its bishop must be respected.  One way to do this is the ancient practice whereby the pope would select the bishop from a terna presented to him by the local church. The terna (three candidates) would emerge from a Synodal or Conciliar process, involving both clergy and laity.

Comment: Alex L. Koplin, your problem isn't math.
You are confusing debt and deficit. 

The deficit is a measure of a single year’s shortfall, the difference between what the government takes in and what it spends. That's currently about $3 billion per year. Taking that money out of the Permanent Fund will only take care of one year. You will have to keep doing it year after year, unless you reduce spending to match revenue.

The debt is the total amount of money the government owes. It represents the accumulation of past deficits, minus surpluses. According to a January 2014 report by the nonprofit organization State Budget Solutions, Alaska had a state debt of approximately $29.8 billion. Its state debt per capita was $40,714.

You could pay this off with a one time payment, but you would still be running a deficit every year, unless you reduce spending to match revenue.

http://www.pgpf.org/blog/2016/10/debt-vs-deficits-whats-the-difference

Comment: I think this article chooses to ignore the more common sense complaints made by those of us who don't like the way this city is currently being developed.  We can accept that some houses will be torn down and replaced with apartments in the name of density, but too often these numbers are used to justify wasteful and short-sighted building practices.  For instance, in the case of the Eastmoreland sequoia lots (a story I imagine developers and sympathizers of this article scoffed at), the neighborhood offered a very viable plan to build two smaller houses on the property without clearcutting the land, along with compensation for preserving the trees.  Such houses would have been more affordable, and saved a valuable public resource: big trees.  This option was rejected because the developer didn't have kit houses of the right size and shape available.  A little creativity, common sense, and smarts could solve both the issue of density and destruction of the things we like about PDX.

Comment: It began as a buttoned-down clarion for Upper Canada's elite. It never, ever rose to its own claimed status as Canada's national newspaper but through the latter part of the twentieth century it did morph into a thinking person's paper - always right of centre but with a sense of social justice. 

Oddly it withered under the ownership of a company (BCE) that might have been expected to drag it kicking and screaming into the digital era. Now back in the hands of Thompson, it continues to flail against the digital destiny ordained for all survivors in the news business.

It struggles with the deck chairs, oblivious of the dark, massive thing just off its bow. It suffers from poor quality content, an incoherent editorial policy, and a confused revenue model. Inexplicably it clings to uninspired, old-guard, two-fingered hacks as if they were life jackets. But its downfall when it comes will be its growing inclination to eshew controversy and stifle debate.

Comment: Insurance companies are large investment firms whose liabilities are the policy obligations they write and whose assets are the securities that they hold against them.  The business is often portrayed as about policy writing prowess and market share.  But, at its core it is about finding a way to have the assets return more than the liabilities.

From this perspective there is no world view in which mark-to-market losses don't matter.  Actuaries take a long term statistical view of markets that ignore tail events, smooths bond returns and is predicated on historical data.  Good investors take a forward looking view, addressing asymmetry created by the path of markets, especially bond markets and seek to inculcate a forward looking view.  They also count on tail events or black swans in their forecasting.

Manulife made a mess of the crisis writing equity market insurance based on the actuarial view.  Now they are trying to pretend that they are profitable on the same actuarial basis.

Comment: Peter, do you realise that natural water cycles are essentially desalination systems that provide rain in a predictable way (unless unsustainably high carbon systems are supported causing climatic change)?

Desalination plants may be required in emergency situations like the one that the Western Cape is currently facing, but it's very important *at the same time* to re-orientate economies away from high carbon (and other forms of ecologically damaging) production and consumption systems, in order to reverse climate change. There is *massive* potential for supporting alternative low carbon living systems that contain huge amounts of carbon within them -when it comes to individuals and their communities especially in low carbon food systems (less meat, no processed food, support a local organic farmer) and low carbon transport systems (how about trying out some public transport?)

Comment: Churches before Constantine: http://www.theworldorbust.com/the-oldest-churches-in-the-world-lchaim/

That took me all of 30 seconds with an Internet search.

I did not "pontificate" about Jesus praying in Hebrew. I said "may" and "might."

Prescinding from what his divine knowledge meant in terms of languages, it is entirely reasonable to suppose he *might* have prayed in, or been conversant in, Hebrew, Aramaic, Greek and Latin. The Jewish Scriptures in his time existed both in Hebrew and in Greek; both were widely used in the Holy Land and the surrounding areas. Hebrew was not used in everyday conversation, but Greek was. Latin was not so common in the East, but it wasn't unknown. Someone engaged in business or a trade might well learn to deal in more than one language, based on who s/he does business with.

I was responding to the assertion that Jesus definitively did *not* use anything but Aramaic at the Last Supper. I don't believe anyone in AD 2017 can know such a thing.

Comment: It is incredibly subjective to assert that liturgical dance equates to "ecstasy of immersion in the restorative grace of boundless mercy and joy".  Even people I know who support liturgical dance would call that a stretch.  Dance in praise of God in scripture was a spontaneous expression of praise, not some choreographed, billowy performance.  And, the Mass provides us with another way to participate in redemptive grace.  It's called the Eucharist.  By receiving the Eucharist, Christ unites us to his resurrected self physically and spiritually.  Why would we "strain a gnat but swallow a camel" by trying to equate liturgical dance to such benefits when it's right there before us staring us in the face?  Actual participation in the Mass means participating in what God already provides us in the Mass, not inventing some other shiny object and calling it active participation for its "incarnational" quality of creating ecstasy and joy or whatever.

Comment: I'm 72 & in the last 10 years I've learned about the cost of retirement homes & nursing homes while assisting my elderly in-laws. Avg. retirement homes cost $35K to $45K per year.  Nursing home rates are set by the govt. & range in the mid-20K's per year  BUT one has to be in need of Nursing home care to qualify as determined by the 'gatekeeper' govt. agency CCAS. Wait times for nursing homes can be 6+ months in some areas. 
Most SR's & their families are surprised or even shocked by these prices as they've never checked out the pricing until they've needed a retirement or nursing home. 
Many elderly widows have low CPP due to limited CPP contibutions (Many didn't work outside their homes) + OAS & GIS.  Many earn only in the $20K range per year, thus far less than Retirement home rates. Unless they have substantial equity in a home than they cannot afford a Retirement home long-term. This is a huge problem that too many elderly & their families are unaware of.

Comment: This is crazy!   The only place in Alaska where clock time is even close to sun time is Southeast during Standard Time.   By the time you move westward to Anchorage, sun time is almost two hours off clock time.   By the time you get to Bethel, Nome, or Kotzebue it is three to four hours off clock time and even around the equinoxes the sun doesn't rise until ten or eleven AM and it is still light at midnight.   In ANC it is merely a bit disorienting, but in the Western parts of the State it has a dramatic effect on the way people live.   Daylight Savings Time is unnecessary and inconvenient, but the biggest thing it does is make the disassociation between sun time and clock time even worse.

Comment: Facing "endtime":
in practical terms, we know our personal life comes to an end. This experiential truth, suggests also that endings and beginnings continually and necessarily recur for all times.
If we accept the responsibility of being "Christlike", then we can understand our personal lives as "Second Comings". Being Christlike is being Eucharistic, recognizing our lives are for other in the ultimate sense -- being 'ecological'.
Being Christlike compels self-giving to Otherness, in our times, in all time. If we are faithful to the universal Call of Second Coming, we will search personal conscience and rediscover what authentic inter-relationship means in the present time. If we all live in conscionable relationship with each other and all other, personal end-time is more a promise than a threat. In this matter we belong to the one and same "church" of common/ mutual belonging. More productive is anticipating personal end-time and affirming well-being for many end-times to come.

Comment: This entire debacle pitting neighbor versus neighbor is the result of poor planning and a "band-aid" solution mentality. U-Med is basically a rough circle and to get to many of the places within the circle almost every driver has to go to the center of the circle (36th/University or 36th/Elmore). Poor planning from the beginning. Stubbornness to not change it. Lack of creativity to not implement low-cost improvements to Northern Lights and Lake Otis that would ease congestion (such as "Coastal" stoplights at NL/University and NL/Bragaw). The "bigger" picture of providing a corridor for Seward-to-Glenn traffic would be a big help. A relatively low-cost/impact project to make a high-speed corridor utilizing Dowling, Elmore, MLK Jr, and Boniface would divert traffic from U-Med. My name is John Zebutis, I am a Republican candidate for State House, east side #27. I don't have all the answers, but I will try to make sure common-sense is at least considered.

Comment: You pose an interesting question.  Mr. Perez was a man of his time, a time that was rapidly changing under his feet, as it were.  If someone were to call him wicked, I probably would not disagree.  The Archbishop of New Orleans formally excommunicated him, not for his vile segregationist ideals alone, but for his direct attacks on the consciences of workers and the wilful destruction of a desegregated school belonging the the archdiocese.  Mr. Perez had broken communion with the Church entirely on his own dime, the excommunication just made that a bit of public knowledge.  He was later reconciled to the faith, retracted his misguided statements, and funded a house of studies, where I, as a child, chanted Morning and Evening prayer each day while I was a theological student.

In his case, I would suppose that the blessed sacrament did function as an engine of reconciliation and mercy.

Not, IMO, a bunch of happy campers, full of "I've got that joy, joy, joy, deep in my heart." They are the killjoys to a classical contribution to the repertoire of music. Many of the great composers depended on church patronage, like artists, to express themselves.

Comment: Although I have never been on welfare, neither have I been wealthy. For most of my life, I have been reasonably healthy. I have a small service-connected disability, but it is only in the past couple of years that I have needed some serious medical care. Without the VA, I doubt I would have been able to afford the care I needed and therefore doubt I would be alive today. This is my 80th year and, believe me, the body is not what it once was. My VA medical care has been more than acceptable, even with trips to Roseburg and, in a couple of cases, Portland and Seattle. Eugene's new clinic is a major improvement over the old River Road one, with the addition of more services such as a lab.

The Trump administration contains many people who want to privatize many aspects of our lives and the VA is one of them. Of course, like all human endeavors, it is not perfect. However, adding millions of vets to the non-VA medical system would overwhelm the already overloaded medical services industry.

Comment: Larry, you just keep repeating the same argument. When Trump leads in a poll it's significant. When Hillary leads in a poll it's not. 

One of the definitions of "significant" is "having a particular meaning; indicative of something."  Clinton's lead in Pennsylvania, up 6.5 %, is significant. Up 7.3% in Michigan is significant. Up 9% in New Hampshire  is significant. In Virginia up 5% is significant. Up 11% in Colorado is significant. 

These swing state polls are lot more indicative of who is going to win the election, than a national popular vote poll, just like they were in 2008 and 2012.  They will bounce around in the next 60 days, but if I were  a candidate, I'd much rather be where Hillary is, than where your boy Trump is.

Comment: Cool.

There is one other place I've seen shaped stone.  Back in the 1970's, I helped map the remains of a heiau on Pu`u Kuki`i in Puna where cut stones were still found strewn about.  Legend has it that the heiau was built under the direction of `Umi a Liloa, a famous Hawai`i Island ali`i.  

Stones from the heiau are reported to have been shipped to Honolulu where Kalakaua used them in the construction of Iolani Palace.

FYI, the Hawaiian word menehune has a cognate in Tahitian manahune, which refers there to commoners.

Hawai`i is the most isolated land mass in the world.  Scholars generally believe the first people here were Polynesians, who were the greatest navigators on earth at the time.  No one else had the know how to sail here.

Comment: I owned an older three bedroom, 1200sqf townhouse in North Vancouver up until Jan 2017. My townhouse complex was sold to Anthem Properties after a 4 year Supreme Court battle. Although we did sign in favour of the sale 5 years ago, the selling power of the owners was taken away and put in the hands of the court. During this 4 year court battle, real estate prices in North Van increased significantly. Therefore, when the case finally closed, we were paid out at a rate very close to what we had originally signed 5 years prior. I was paid out aprox $500,000 for a 3 bedroom townhouse in January 2017.  Older, rundown  3 bed townhouse in North Vancouver currently list for aprox $700,000, but these are limited as new builds take over. The result of this once hopeful opportunity has been disastrous. It has pushed many young families (specifically 6 so far) out of North Vancouver in search of lower cost housing. Like myself, most of these people were born, raised, and worked in North Vancouver.

Comment: My gosh, Rationalis, you appear not to grasp the inherent contradiction in your own words. In the same sentence you say "abortion is the killing of a ... PERSON" and then "the fetus is a POTENTIAL person." 

When you say that the fetus is only a "potential person," you grant to the "pro-abortionist" philosopher the very essence of their argument. A potential human is not yet a full human, it is a life growing, developing towards full humanity. Since the fetus is, according to you, not yet fully a person, then the secular moral agreement that we can not take the life of persons, does NOT apply to the fetus.

Au contraire, the Catholic position is that the fetus is a full human being in the most essential manner that makes humans, humans from the perspective of our theology. The fetus has been "ensouled" (to use an older terminology that has its own problems) and is thus immortal long before it is born. For us immortality is the essential distinguishing feature of humans versus animals.

Comment: Disgusting Title, Misleading Article - Ms. Kelly attended the LAB meeting but missed nuance and opted to use inflammatory language. All APL computers have internet filters. If you are over 18, you may show ID and have the filter removed. Libraries are full of material that may be found objectionable. Librarians balance this through careful collections choices. Internet access is important for library patrons, but APL cannot choose what is viewed. APL is open to the entire community, and we are very diverse. Porn makes an easy target, but also discussed in the meeting were violent movies, video games, ISIS videos, cookbooks, and foreign language materials. All have been viewed by patrons, and found objectionable by others. What the policy under discussion seeks to do is allow patrons who feel uncomfortable to seek trained library staff who can approach the user with the Code of Conduct rules. Please consider reading the policies and attending the next LAB meeting to voice an opinion.

Comment: There are lists I've read for that address and others nearby. These lists are public information. What used, when, and where. The Weekly publishes it too. 

Do they make profits? I guess they do, because they keep on keeping on. But what magic sprays will rescue tree plantations from drought, beetle infestation and conflagration? What potential boondoggle-villes! Profit über alles!

As I've said here before, I've been employed as a tractor driver out in Lorane, and I get plenty of outside time to see what's happening. I've witnessed scotch broom proliferate despite spraying, blackberries too.

 While there may yet be paltry profit to eke out of the squalorous plantations, the golden days of lumbering are over. The mega-corporate outfits are going to further automate and mechanize workers out of jobs without so much as a thought.

The centralized collapsing of the timber industry in the Pacific Northwest is a microcosm of how the prior century of irrational exuberance is now imploding.

Comment: Trump brings to the presidency a unique combination of arrogance, ignorance, bigotry, incompetence, and emotional instability. He is a president-elect who is manifestly unfit to be president. I think Fr. Reese is right that many people have reacted to the election by moving through the stages of grief. I think it is important, though, that we don't get stuck in denial. There are two ways (at least) in which denial can get in our way as we go forward: 
1.) We can't deny the fact that this man has been elected. For sure, we need to study the election and understand what happened. But we have to accept the outcome.
2.) We can't deny or minimize how dangerously incompetent the president-elect is. We can't indulge a thought that begins with "Maybe it won't be so bad." We need to trust our Constitution and our democratic institutions, believing that they are sturdy enough to restrain and contain the worst impulses of this reckless, dangerous man. But we can't deny how dangerous he is.

Comment: Where to start? 

Your rights as a Canadian are not subject to the mistaken views of others, least of all anonymous comments on an online forum. What a world we would live in if the fears and hatred of others determined our rights. 

It was cowardly of the Liberals to weasel on their assisted dying legislation. Worse yet, their law was a prima facie violation of the Charter right identified by the Supreme Court. Worst of all, the victims of that violation are the most afflicted and most helpless people in Canadian society. You can make excuses for it if you like, but I see a 100% avoidable mistake that perpetuates great suffering.

The Liberal's failure on this law is all their own. They ignored the recommendations of both the committee they struck on the matter, and the Senate's amendments. It's yourself that's bringing partisan politics into it. Harper never had any time to enact legislation. He was defeated just months after he struck his own committee to look into it.

Every special forces unit gives certain members extra training in combat first aid, and in his unit that was Speer. However he carried weapons and was prepared to use them just like any other combat soldier.

The laws of war are clear concerning medics. They must wear an identifying insignia, such as a red cross on their clothing. They may NOT take part in any combat duties. They may only carry a sidearm, and that is only to be used to protect the sick and injured under their care.

Sgt. Speer did none of those things. The instant he went into potential battle with any survivors in the bombed compound, he was an ordinary combatant.

Comment: I can tell you that thought is what delayed me from using it.  My landing was not without problems.  Reserves don't steer as well as primary canopies.  Mine was a typical dome chute with three openings in the back where trapped air would escape.  By pulling on the risers, I could partially collapse those openings which would "steer" the chute.  However, it was sluggish compared to canopies, so I couldn't steer out of a ravine.  I broke my tibia just above the ankle because of it.

However, I'd give that up for what happened to this young man.  I am curious why he didn't use his reserve.  My tangled chute caused me to spin, and when I managed to open a few cells on one side, it started swinging me violently where I could barely bring my hands in to pull the reserve.  He didn't seem to be having that issue.  I'm guessing he was simply concentrating on untangling his chute by pulling apart on his risers.

Comment: As a faculty member at a university allow me to present a different point of view. My institute dropped membership in  Access Copyright after they tried to hugely increase the fees while also adding extremely onerous new terms and restrictions. Instead they directed the funds saved towards a copyright office which vets course material to ensure compliance with the law.

In addition, some of us faculty have got so fed up with dealing with overpriced academic publishers and increasingly onerous copyright laws that we have published our own course notes using the incredibly cheap online publishers available. This has reduced the cost of textbooks for students in my courses from ~$200 to zero if they can live with a PDF (as ~90% do) or US$5+postage if they want a printed book from Amazon's CreateSpace. That's where your royalty payments have gone: measures to completely avoid or ensure compliance with increasingly complex and onerous copyright laws.

Comment: Several comments have condemned the suspensions because the racist posts were done outside of school hours.

School law is based on concepts not that different from workplace law - where employees often enough are fired or disciplined for their comments or actions outside of work. Justifications include impact on the employer's image, and impact on the work-place atmosphere.

In Ontario, here's how section 310 of the Education Act sets out a school's obligation to suspend:

"A Principal shall suspend a pupil if he or she believes that the pupil has engaged in any of the following activities while at school, at a school-related activity or in other circumstances where engaging in the activity will have an impact on the school climate:"

Comment: One interesting "actual fact", IJHB: in many residential schools, the death rate among "students" (or inmates, or victims, if you prefer) was as high as 50%.  
Sez who? 
Dr. Peter Bryce, Medical Inspector, Dept. of the Interior and Indian Affairs. He made a special inspection of 35 schools in the prairie provinces in 1907. The experience shocked him.  Newspaper articles appeared.  In 1922, Bryce retired and wrote a book: The Story of a National Crime; Being a Record of the Health Conditions of the Indians of Canada from 1904 to 1921.  

Many of the deaths were due to TB.  Bryce found on more than one occasion, that infected kids were mingled with uninfected, healthy kids. Many survivors (which means, of school life in the 1940s-1970s, told of experiences similar to what Bryce had found, decades before. Many of the healthy kids were scared to death--they felt it was a DELIBERATE strategy.  Said one: "they wanted us dead."

Read more on Kevin Annett's website.  Annett's word: Genocide.

Comment: The system has been in place in Canada for decades for HRSDC to issue a  Labour Market Impact Assessment (LMIA) formerly a Labour Market Opinion (LMO) ) to a specific employer for a specific job for a named TFW unless there is a specific exemption (such as a Mexican or American  professional under NAFTA).  The LMIA certifies that the particular job meets the Canadian standards for wages, working conditions, etc and that there are no Canadian Citizens or Permanent Residents reasonably available to fill the job.
http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/resources/tools/temp/work/opinion/

In certain sectors such as high tech where there is a clear shortage of workers, sector LMIAs  for specific occupations have been issued in the past.

It was a myth perpetrated by some that there was no clearance procedure.  That was an "alternate fact".

Comment: I've been watching the weather changes, and indeed, studded tires are becoming necessary in more parts of the state.  I don't like having to buy new studded tires every three thousand miles though, as the studs wear out by then.  Tire shops won't re-stud my old tires because of insurance liability.  Seems that they used to re-stud, but they wouldn't put in the labor to clean out the stud holes of grit.  That grit made it possible for a stud to come out during high speed cornering, which caused the insurance companies to quit insuring re-studded work, I guess.
It's costing me about 600 bucks for stud removal and insertion air tools.  I already have a good air tool kit w/compressor/tank.  But that expense will be more than justified, as all my friends and neighbors will be free to use my tools, paying only for the studs that they use, at about 20 cents each.  So, For about 10 bucks per tire, we will be able to re-stud all four, every year.

Comment: EMTALA does not allow you to get treatment for anything but an emergency medical condition, and the only obligation is to stabilize, not cure or resolve the underlying causes of the emergency. 

It works like this. You show up at the ER with severe shortness of breath caused by your lung cancer. The  ER staff has to screen you for an emergency medical condition and can't delay the screening while asking how you're going to pay. Severe dyspnea is an emergency, so the ER staff would likely treat you with several medications. They may do imaging and admit you if you're still significantly laboring to breath. You might even get a chemo or radiation treatment or two. But, as soon as you are you are stable, the hospital can and likely will discharge you. 

No one has an obligation to further treat you until you are again in severe distress. 

Plus, you remain liable under normal civil law for the cost of your treatment. The hospital can and likely will bill you and pursue collection.

Comment: Single payer meets both the moral requirement and the fiscal requirement: it guarantees healthcare to all, free on demand, while at the same time saving the vast majority of US residents money and saving the government money as well. The only objection to a medicare for all system comes from people who think that others deserve to suffer, that people deserves to be denied potentially life-saving care because they don't meet certain requirements. This is a vicious, cruel position that should not be entertained. That fact is that if we approach this from a position of either humanitarian interest or self interest, single payer becomes the only viable option. It saves us money, it guarantees us care, and it guarantees our neighbors care as well. If you care about yourself, support single payer. If you care about your neighbor, support single payer. If you want other people to suffer even at the expense of your own wallet and well-being, your opinion doesn't matter.

Comment: The crusaders took the city, deposed Alexios III and set up Prince Alexios as Emperor Alexios IV. Alexios III fled to what is now western Greece.

Alexios IV tried to redeem his promises, but couldn't. There was no money in the treasury, and even when he seized the assets of his enemies (and grabbed a lot from the Church), he was unable to come up with the full amount he promised the crusaders. None of his subjects, from the Patriarch of Constantinople on down, had the slightest interest in being under the pope. No one in the Byzantine army wanted to attack Saladin, who was the finest military leader in the region -- and with whom the civil government was on remarkably good terms, so the civilian authorities had no interest in going to war with him either. Besides, there was no money available for a war.

Comment: I live in Colorado and have worked with a small group of ordinary Coloradans to develop the structure and goals of ColoradoCare for the past 4 years. We would rather see a comprehensive national single-payer plan implemented.  However, the divisiveness and gridlock in Congress have caused us to decide starting a state plan (not true single-payer, but as close as we can manage) is the only viable way to proceed at this point.

We are up against the insurance industry, the Koch brothers, and an endless array of knee jerk reactionaries and right wingnuts who insist the sky would fall and screaming things like "death panels", "socialized medicine" and "doctors will leave the state."

The opposition think of themselves as "patriots", but cannot bring themselves to believe that we Americans can create a healthcare system as good as, or better than, the systems in operation in every other major, industrialized democracy.

Please go to COLORADOCARE.ORG for more information.  Thanks Oregon!

Comment: I was homeless for almost a year and found it difficult to find a safe space to sleep. I was heartened by the stance of the Kailua-Kona Commission that they've endeavoured to create a safe space for homeless people. Many families become homeless also, because their breadwinner had a job, but through exigent circumstances is now homeless. The situation where children now are homeless and missing or not attending school at all, is a tragedy of major proportions, leaving the children of homeless parents vulnerable to continued poverty, ill health and many other consequences, unintended but happening nonetheless. 

America, the richest nation in the world, continues to have homeless, most if not all of them with some form of disease or mental health issues. We must put our monies where our mouths are, and demand that even before a bloated military budget becomes a fixed property, that we take care of our homeless and helpless citizens. This must be the focus of our budgetary concerns,.

Comment: The theme here is "EVERYONE needs skin in the game". Our State is now a triage State. Cuts & cash both needed, and quick!
That includes oil  - starting with the incentives that are not "real" incentives, but gifts. But it also includes taxes on all major transaction sectors - fisheries, mining, alcohol, tobacco - and I'd add at least seasonal docking taxes at cruise ship ports, and interstate airports:
An income tax of $200/yr on $60,000/yr?  And it captures major revenue from non-Alaskans? Sounds pretty reasonable!
As for budget cuts - they've been happening & will continue - I hope over 2-5 years, not all at once.
Real government dependent jobs & spending are disappearing - and those pushing quicker cuts may think twice when they see -as in the late '80's - half the homes in their neighborhood vacant and for sale. Government spending in AK is job spending. Believe me, your LOCAL (not State) property values and property taxes ARE  going to fall sharply - but you won't really like it.

Comment: Great quote from Rob: "As for returns, they can only be judged when compared to an appropriate mix of benchmark stock and bond indexes. Advisers who earn their fees will make this sort of comparison available to their clients." The problem is the industry specializes in smoke and mirrors. 18-page statements and pie charts that mean nothing. I have also seen advisors compare themselves the TSX but leaving out dividends in the benchmark to make themselves look better. Average Joe has no chance of knowing they are being manipulated.  A good place to start would be to look at SPIVA, just Google it. Standard and Poors Index vs Active and understand how most funds perform compared to the benchmark.  If your advisor does not tell you 1) what rate of return and inflation you need to achieve your goal/ plan 2) what you made after fees 3) what the benchmark made then it's likely because they don't want you to know.

Comment: I find your commentary one-sided and simplistic in the sense that you seem to assign all power of decision to Trump and his administration. But there are three complete negotiating teams from three countries meeting together, and the outcome will surely be determined by them. No one country, much less one individual, can "pull the plug" on NAFTA because it is a trilateral agreement. Lots of contentious issues have developed over the years, which no doubt the current talks will aim to solve. But all three countries have indicated that they are prepared to walk away from a deal which is disadvantageous to them. So, like all agreements and renegotiations of agreements, there will have to be something good for each country for them to sign on. The whole thing will be much more interesting and unpredictable than you suggest.

Comment: Correct Tony, but it was not only the last time, it was the only time the only time the WHO tried to rank health care systems. Yes, the methodology and data was significant flawed. The WHO abandoned it.   

The WHO gave up trying to "rank" systems and now just tries to provide statistics by indicators. So if one actually Googles "World Heath Organization (WHO) 2016 Statistics", this is what you get:     http://www.who.int/gho/publications/world_health_statistics/2016/en/

This is a primarily a comparative report on health status, not health system. Certainly no ranking and the vast majority of the health status measures are not very strongly related to the health system, they reflect socio-economic conditions and status. 

All in all, when someone cites the WHO health system ranking, you know it is a person who knows nothing about health or health care systems.

Comment: The Single-Member-Constituency system presently used, but modified with Ranked Ballots to permit people to express their second and third choices, should ensure that everyone has at least the chance of getting their second choice elected. Comment: Yes, and a lot of the job ads are from businesses, especially the temp agencies, which are just collecting applications and don't really have a job to offer. 

Before I retired, mostly from office work, I found job hunting, which I had to do every time I got laid off, very frustrating. You can answer lots of ads and send in lots of resumes, and nobody calls you for a job interview. 

The official unemployment rate doesn't include people who have given up, because no one will hire them. A while back I read that employers were automatically rejecting applications from anyone who had been out of work for six months or more, on the theory that if no one else wanted them neither did they. 

Like landlords, employers can afford to be very picky. Often the requirements to apply for a job are way higher than the job actually needs, which allows them to reject a lot of applications and make their hiring process easier. It's not a very rational process.

Comment: It is tragic that people go hungry in the modern world, but it is wrong to blame supermarkets.  Pick n Pay had a net profit margin of 1.6% as at end February 2017.  It is more-or-less impossible to run a business on thinner margins.  Competition between the major supermarket chains keeps them efficient.  In Pick n Pay's case, on a turnover of R77.5 billion they paid away R63.5 billion to suppliers.  There is no other system that will get products to consumers more cost-effectively.  There may be problems elsewhere in the supply chain, but supermarkets are not the problem.

Comment: Speakplain907, I learned this many years ago and I hold it as one of the key truths that exist: 

You cannot stop any problem from the supply side. 

What that refers to is the supply/demand curve from basic economics. Where there is a demand, there will be a supply to meet that demand. All we try to do (and fail every day) is to limit the supply side. We prohibit. We fine. We dump out bottles. We fail, every day. 

You cannot lock it down because someone will come up with more novel ways to sneak it in. Guaranteed. The only way to ever fight a dangerous substance is to fight it on the demand side. As long as rural villagers need alcohol, they will get it. End of story. 

So you can label a community "dry" as much as you want and pretend that accomplishes anything. It hasn't, doesn't, and won't accomplish anything. You can *only* convince people they do not want alcohol, either through providing massive resources for counseling OR providing a safer alternative (cough cough).

Tesla plans 18 gigafactories world wide to supply the demand for batteries.

There are thousands of parts in every engine. transmission and drivetrain just to move a gas car forward & backward. "The Sun gives us more energy than we can ever use..everyday."  Nikola Tesla.   Tesla style EV's will get inexpensive as they are made in mass production.There is only a shell, interior, wheels, 3 stage electric motor, wiring harness, battery, inverter to change from battery DC to AC and a forward/reverse gear box. 

The world is converting to solar as it should.  The transition to EV's will happen much faster than predicted..two-3 years at the most. 

We may all breathe easier.

Comment: I don't buy the results of this survey.  What you are seeing here are the voices of highly-motivated survey takers (i.e., those who really want to see this proposed idea succeed).  Like it or not, the vast majority Albertans do not do very well with change of any kind.  In the current political environment,  the best advice for the NDP government might simply be to "keep their heads down, and manage effectively."  They have two years to build up a record of financial competence (or repair the damage they have already done).  I get it, the NDP are looking for a win - especially with rural folks.  However, this time-change issue is a small, distraction, that will most certainly come back to haunt the party - reinforcing the social-engineering, activist narrative. Recall Steven Harper's effort to tinker with the long-form census? An issue that should have been a small thing - satisfying a vocal minority - sadly turned into a festering self-inflicted wound.

Comment: This conflict hasn't been going on for 2,000 years. It started in the early 1900's when the Zionist movement brought an influx of Jewish immigrants looking to establish a homeland in Palestine. Things were rocky from the start, but it became even worse post-WWII in 1947 when the UN & Britain hacked up Palestine to create Israel. Yes, Palestine is mostly Muslim and Israel is mostly Jewish, and religious tensions certainly don't help matters, but at it's heart, it's a land dispute that's been going on roughly 100 years at most (though 70 years might be a more apt description).

Comment: That's 'Hajji' to you.  Only my mom has permission to call me 'Freddy' and she doesn't. My offspring are of African-American, Syrian Arab, Fijian, Puerto Rican, Spaniard, Welsh, Scottish, French, German, English and (allegedly) Choctaw and Malagasy heritage. Comment: Good editorial. I would take the "the nuances of progressive policy" one step further and suggest the fundamental issue is between faux progressives who are neoliberal more than anything else, and progressives who are truly democratic leftists. Nikkita Oliver says this election is about who will have the right to live in this city over the next few years. 

Exactly; who has a "right to the city" (please look it up) is exactly what we're deciding in this election.

Candidates who want Vulcan's support to run will not be inclined to afford the "right to the city" to those who are below the average median income (AMI). Gentrification and displacement will continue if we elect yet another mayor and council member(s) who represent developer interests first. 

As you observe, in Seattle all candidates will sound liberal, but most will indeed have more or less "neo" in the policies and actions they promote. Come on Seattle; haven't you had enough? Let's elect some real progressives for once.

Comment: Couple of things here. The GOP ceased being a "Party" when the Tea Party hijacked it, perhaps even before that if you consider the pandering to the religious right.  Allowing Trump on the ticket only cemented the descent into a cabal at odds with itself.  At best it's a fractured coalition. Today's GOP used to place the good of the country as a whole before that of single classes.  But then there were only a dozen planks in the party platform too.  To refer to those calling the shots "leadership" in the face of the chaos that has been legislative process is ludicrous. They do to, but it's tough to do the right thing.  Always has been.
